item.title: Live. Die. Repeat. Is the 'Privacy Shield' deal stuck in a never-ending cycle of repeating the same mistakes like in the movie 'Groundhog Day'?
item.description:
Steve Peers While the USA is globally recognized, some of its customs remain perplexing. Take “Groundhog Day,” where the presence or absence of a groundhog’s shadow on February 2nd supposedly predicts six more weeks of winter. Beyond the USA, it’s more famous as a film where Bill Murray relives the same day, striving for perfection and Andie MacDowell’s affections. item.title: Is the Commission's draft EU-US Privacy Shield adequacy decision a new shield for transatlantic privacy or just more of the same?
item.description:
Dr. Maria Tzanou (Lecturer in Law, Keele University) In October 2015, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) ruled in the Schrems case that the US Safe Harbor framework did not adequately protect personal data transfers from the EU. The court found that US mass electronic surveillance practices violated fundamental EU privacy rights. To address this, the European Commission and the US agreed on a new framework called the EU-US Privacy Shield...

item.title: The Attorney General's opinion in the Schrems II case: Facebook, national security, and laws on data protection.
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex Recently, a CJEU Advocate-General presented an opinion on the Schrems II case, which centers on the legality of US national security regulations regarding personal data transfers from the EU, specifically through Facebook. This case follows the impactful Schrems I ruling that invalidated the EU-US data transfer agreement due to insufficient protections against surveillance under US law.
